Furthermore, the suffering and happiness experienced by sentient beings are all due to their lives. If so, the Jains and others originally had evil lives.
Why is it so?
Because of this, the Jains now experience extremely severe suffering. This is called the third despicable thing about the Jains.
Furthermore, the suffering and happiness experienced by sentient beings are all due to their views.
If so, the Jains and others originally had evil views.
Why is it so?
Because of this, the Jains now experience extremely severe suffering. This is called the fourth contemptible thing about the Jains.
Furthermore, if sentient beings' suffering and happiness are all created by a supreme being, then the Jains' supreme being is evil.
Why is this?
Because of this, the Jains now experience extremely severe suffering. This is called the fifth contemptible thing about the Jains.

If the Jains' evil deeds, evil gatherings, evil livelihood, evil views, and evil supreme being were created by an evil supreme being, because of this, the Jains now experience extremely severe suffering. This is called the reason why the Jains are contemptible.
The Dharma that I have personally known and realized, which I teach to you, cannot be refuted, defiled, or obstructed by any ascetic, brahmin, god, MÄra, BrahmÄ, or anyone else in the world.

How is it that I have attained the Dharma through self-realization and self-enlightenment, which cannot be subdued, defiled, or controlled by ascetics, brahmins, gods, demons, BrahmÄ, or anyone else in the world?

If a bhiká¹£u abandons unwholesome bodily actions and cultivates wholesome bodily actions, abandons unwholesome verbal and mental actions and cultivates wholesome verbal and mental actions, he will know for himself in the future that he will have no suffering, and will attain happiness according to the Dharma without abandoning it.

If he wishes to end the cause of suffering, he may practice desire or practice the abandonment of desire. If he wishes to end the cause of suffering and practices desire, he will cultivate the practice of desire and end it, and suffering will be exhausted.
If he wishes to end the cause of suffering and practices the abandonment of desire, he will cultivate the practice of abandoning desire and end it, and suffering will be exhausted.
If that bhiká¹£u thinks like this:

'Whatever I do and wherever I go, unwholesome states arise and wholesome states diminish. If I were to end my own suffering, unwholesome states would diminish and wholesome states would increase. I should now end my own suffering.'
He then ended his own suffering.
After ending his own suffering, unwholesome states diminished and wholesome states increased, and he no longer ended his own suffering.
Why is it so?
Bhikkhus!
What he originally did, its meaning has already been accomplished. If he were to end his suffering again, this would not be right.
Bhikkhus!
It is just as an arrow-maker uses a string to straighten an arrow. When the arrow is straight, he does not use the string again.
Why is it so?
Because what that person originally did, its matter has already been accomplished. If he were to use the string again, this would not be right.
In the same way, the bhikkhu then had this thought:

'Whatever I do and wherever I go, unwholesome states arise and wholesome states diminish. If I were to end my own suffering, unwholesome states would diminish and wholesome states would arise. I should now end my own suffering.'
He then ended his own suffering.
After ending his own suffering, unwholesome states diminished and wholesome states arose, and he no longer ended his own suffering.
Why is that?
The original purpose has already been accomplished. If he were to end his own suffering again, that would be unreasonable.
Monks!

Suppose there was a man who loved, was attached to, and respected a woman, but that woman spoke to another man, exchanged greetings with him, went to stay with him. Would that man, because of that, experience mental and physical suffering, extreme distress?'
The monks replied:
'Yes, World-Honored One.
Why is that?

The man would love and be attached to the woman, treat her with utmost respect, but if the woman were to speak to others, exchange greetings with them, come and go, and stay overnight, how could the man's body and mind not give rise to suffering, distress, and worry?
Bhiká¹£us!
If that man were to think:

'I have loved and respected that woman in vain. She speaks to others, exchanges greetings with them, comes and goes, and stays overnight. I should now cut off my love and attachment to her because of my own suffering and worry.'
Later, because of his own suffering and worry, he would then cut off his love and attachment to that woman.

If that woman still speaks to others, exchanges greetings with them, comes and goes, and stays overnight, would the man's body and mind later still give rise to suffering, extreme distress, and worry?
The bhiká¹£us replied:
No, World-Honored One!
Why is it so?

If that person no longer has any affection or attachment towards the woman, and if that woman still talks to others, greets them, comes and goes, and stays overnight, causing that person to again experience suffering and extreme distress, this is not the case.
In this way, the bhiká¹£u thinks like this:

'According to what is done and what is practiced, unwholesome dharmas arise and wholesome dharmas cease. If one cuts off one's own suffering, unwholesome dharmas cease and wholesome dharmas arise. I should now cut off my own suffering.
' He then cuts off his own suffering.
After cutting off his own suffering, unwholesome dharmas cease and wholesome dharmas arise. He no longer cuts off his suffering.
Why is it so?
The original purpose has already been accomplished. If he cuts off his suffering again, this is not the case.
He further thinks like this:
'If there is a cause for this, and if cutting it off would end my suffering, then I would have already cut it off. However, I have not yet cut off desire. I should now seek to cut off desire.'
So he sought to cut off desire.

In order to cut off desire, he lived alone in seclusion, in a place free from business, either under a tree or in an empty, quiet place, a mountain cave, a stone chamber, in the open, a straw pile, or in a forest, or in a charnel ground. Having already gone to a place free from business, or under a tree or in an empty, quiet place, he spread out his sitting mat, sat cross-legged, straightened his body, and set his intentions right. He turned his thoughts back, not outward, cut off covetousness, had no disputes in his mind, and did not give rise to covetousness for others' wealth and possessions, wishing to obtain them for himself. He purified his mind of covetousness.
In the same way, he cut off anger, sleepiness, restlessness and remorse, and resolved doubts and confusion. He had no hesitation regarding wholesome dharmas. He purified his mind of doubt.

Having cut off these five hindrances, having weakened the defilements of the mind, he attains and abides in the fourth jhÄna, which is neither painful nor pleasant and includes the purification of mindfulness by equanimity.

Having attained such concentration, his mind is purified and cleansed, without defilements, pliable, workable, and established in immovable equipoise. He directs his mind to the knowledge of the destruction of the taints. He knows as it really is: 'This is suffering,' 'This is the origin of suffering,' 'This is the cessation of suffering,' and 'This is the path leading to the cessation of suffering.' He knows as it really is: 'These are the taints,' 'This is the origin of the taints,' 'This is the cessation of the taints,' and 'This is the path leading to the cessation of the taints.' Having known and seen thus, his mind is liberated from the taint of sensual desire, from the taint of existence, and from the taint of ignorance. When it is liberated, there arises the knowledge: 'It is liberated.' He knows: 'Birth is ended, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more coming to any state of being.'
The TathÄgata, thus rightly liberated in mind, has attained five praises, in accordance with the Dharma, without dispute, lovable and respectable.

What are the five?ğŸ”½Those beings' suffering and happiness are all caused by their past actions. If so, the TathÄgata had wonderful actions in the past, and because of them, the TathÄgata now attains the holy, undefiled bliss, peaceful and tranquil, and experiences the bliss of liberation. This is called the TathÄgata's attainment of the first praise.

Furthermore, the suffering and happiness experienced by beings are all caused by their combination [of causes and conditions]. Furthermore, the suffering and happiness experienced by sentient beings are all due to the cause of life. If so, the TathÄgata's original wonderful life is the cause of that. This is called the TathÄgata's attainment of the third praise.ğŸ”½Furthermore, the suffering and happiness experienced by sentient beings are all due to views. Furthermore, the suffering and happiness experienced by sentient beings are all due to the creation of revered blessings. If so, the TathÄgata's original wonderful revered blessings are the cause of that. Therefore, the TathÄgata now attains the holy, undefiled bliss, the bliss of tranquility and cessation, and experiences the bliss of awakening. This is the TathÄgata's original wondrous karma, wondrous union, wondrous life, wondrous vision, and wondrous blessings. It is created by the wondrous blessings, and because of that, the TathÄgata now attains the holy, undefiled bliss, peaceful cessation, and the realization of bliss. For this reason, the TathÄgata now attains five praises.
There are five causes and conditions that give rise to mental anguish and suffering.
What are the five?
One who is bound by sexual desire, due to being bound by sexual desire, gives rise to mental anguish and suffering.
Similarly, one who is bound by anger, sleep, restlessness, remorse, and doubt, due to being bound by doubt, gives rise to mental anguish and suffering.
These are the five causes and conditions that give rise to mental anguish and suffering.
There are five causes and conditions that extinguish mental anguish and suffering.
What are the five?

If one is bound by lust, due to being bound by lust, one's mind gives rise to sorrow and suffering. If one removes the binding of lust, the sorrow and suffering will cease. Due to being bound by lust, one's mind gives rise to sorrow and suffering. In this very life, one attains the ultimate, free from vexation and heat, always abiding and unchanging, which is known and seen by the sages.

In the same way, if one is bound by anger, sloth, restlessness, remorse, or doubt, due to being bound by doubt, one's mind gives rise to sorrow and suffering. If one removes the binding of doubt, the sorrow and suffering will cease. Due to being bound by doubt, one's mind gives rise to sorrow and suffering. In this very life, one attains the ultimate, free from vexation and heat, always abiding and unchanging, which is known and seen by the sages.
These are the five causes for the cessation of sorrow and suffering in the mind.
Furthermore, there is another way to attain the ultimate in this very life, free from vexation and heat, always abiding and unchanging, which is known and seen by the sages.
How can there be another present Dharma that can be attained to the end, free from vexation and heat, eternally abiding and unchanging, which is known by the sages and seen by the sages?
It is the eightfold noble path, right view up to right concentration, totaling eight.
This is called another present Dharma that can be attained to the end, free from vexation and heat, eternally abiding and unchanging, which is known by the sages and seen by the sages.

In the northern village, I have built a high hall, laid out bedding, set up water vessels, and lit bright lamps. If there are diligent Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as who come to stay in the high hall, I provide them with what they need according to my ability.
There are four debaters whose views differ and contradict each other. They have gathered in the high hall.

In this regard, the first debater holds this view and makes this proclamation: 'There is no giving, no sacrifice, no offerings; there are no results or fruits of good or bad actions; there is no this world or next world, no mother or father; there are in the world no ascetics or brahmins who have practiced rightly, who have realized for themselves by direct knowledge and dwell having directly realized this world and the next world, and having experienced it by their own super-knowledge.'
The second debater holds the right view, which is the opposite of the first debater's view and knowledge. He sees thus and speaks thus:
'There is giving, there is sacrifice, there are offerings;
there are results and fruits of good and bad actions;

in the world there are ascetics and brahmins who have practiced rightly, who have realized for themselves by direct knowledge and dwell having directly realized this world and the next world, and having experienced it by their own super-knowledge.'

The third debater sees and speaks like this: 'One who kills, steals, engages in sexual misconduct, speaks falsely, drinks alcohol, digs through walls, opens up treasuries, robs in other people's lanes, harms villages, destroys towns, breaks through cities, and annihilates countries;
One who does such things does not do evil.

Moreover, with an iron wheel as sharp as a razor, they cut, slice, chop, peel, tear, and slash all beings on this earth in a single day, making a single piece of flesh, a single portion, a single pile. Because of this, there is no evil karma, and because of this, there is no retribution for evil karma.

To the south of the Ganges River, one kills, cuts, and cooks; to the north of the Ganges River, one gives, observes the precepts, and recites spells. Because of this, there is no sin or merit, and because of this, there is no retribution for sin or merit.

Giving, taming, guarding, upholding, praising, benefiting, giving generously, speaking kindly, benefiting, and equalizing benefits, due to these there is no merit, and due to these there is no reward for merit.

The fourth debater has right views and refutes what the third debater knows and sees, saying, 'Seeing like this, speaking like this, one kills oneself and teaches others to kill, cuts oneself and teaches others to cut, cooks oneself and teaches others to cook, worries and grieves, beats one's chest in distress, weeps and is foolish, kills, takes what is not given, engages in sexual misconduct, speaks falsely, drinks alcohol, digs through walls to open storehouses, robs in other people's lanes, harms villages, destroys towns, breaks through cities, and annihilates countries;
doing such things is truly doing evil.
